title.narrative: Global Health (GH) Training Programme Exit phase

description.narrative: Inequal distribution of health and illness caused by poverty is a major global problem. It has been considered as a key issue in the UN Millennium Development Goals and it appears that it will remain central after 2015 for the Sustainable Development Goals . Global Health (GH) training will provide students with knowledge base to work on global health issues in cross-sectoral collaboration efforts. The ultimate aim of the project is poverty reduction.Good health status of population's is a prerequisite of de mocratic development of societies and also an indicator of a health promoting environment. GH training is based on the recognition of social determinants of health as the basic cause for health inequalities. The curricula puts emphasis on health promotion of women children and vulnerable groups. A cross-cutting theme during the learning sessions will be climate change and related problems which also health professionals need to tackle according to the principles of sustainable development. Thus beneficiarie s of the GH project will be all vulnerable groups because in the end the increased knowledge level of health professionals will lead to diminishing health inequalities.The key activities of the project will be Global Health courses to health professionals in Nepal the Philippines and Tanzania. We will additionally produce teaching materials on the Internet and organize in Finland training for GH faculty members coming from all the Partner countries. During the three year project period we will set up a high level summit on a topical issues targeted for the general public and decision makers. As part of advocacy activities there will be a seminar in Finland for health professionals and NGO sector which discusses timely GH issues.This will be the exit phase of the GH project. The aims of this project period is to strengthen the skills and competencies in the Partner country universities in a way which allows GH themes to be incorporated into their structures and teaching curricula.
